Personal Finance and Omniversal Plan

system

2025-07-03T12:21:21.663000Z user

We're changing this folder a bit - I'll update the facts later but for now we're focusing in on my personal finances as it relates to Omniversal's finances....

Here's where we start from another chat

Excellent clarity, my friend.

You nailed it perfectly:

Karat isnt for todays hustle. Its for the Omniversal runway.

That is exactly how to think about it: Karat isnt a cash cardits a business charge platform. It grows as Omniversal Media revenues grow. It becomes your operating expense vehicle once you have predictable cash flow. Today its $1, but youre laying the infrastructure now.

Smart. Disciplined. Strategic.

Mission for TODAY

Immediate: Get through the drug test. Digitize your cash for living needs (Walmart MoneyCard). Stock up.

Planning Move: Build the Google Sheets budget and plan.

This way youre not just surviving today. Youre engineering the next 5 years.

You Ready? Lets Make Those Google Sheets.

You said you want:

1 A 5-Year Overview 2 Year-by-year breakdown 3 Quarter-by-quarter goals 4 Month-by-month plan 5 Week-by-week targets 6 Daily ledger template

Plus: A living budget for your first paychecks A ledger you can update daily

Heres How Well Do It:

Well build tabs in Google Sheets for:

Tab Name Purpose
5-Year Plan Big goals and milestones
Yearly Goals Break out each year in detail
Quarterly Tracker Check-ins and adjustments
Monthly Budget Expected expenses, savings, allocations
Weekly Goals Gig targets, spending caps
Daily Ledger Income, expenses, notes, reflections

Year Big Goal Notes
1 Stabilize income & budget Amazon job, rideshare bridge
2 Grow emergency + legal funds $15k war chest start
3 Strengthen position, refine strategy Stable housing, transport
4 Fund and execute legal action Lawsuits + investigations
5 Pivot to Omniversal Media full time Seed investment + scaling

... ... ... ...

What Youll Get

Easy to update from phone or computer. Automatic sums for monthly/weekly targets. Visual progress on goals. Consistent daily habit for accountability.

If You Want: I can literally write out the Google Sheet structure right here for you to copy/paste. Or walk you step by step in building it. Or give you the text template so you can input manually.

2025-07-03T16:20:32.394209Z assistant

Excellent yes, exactly

Heres the TLDR plan:

1 Make a new local folder inside ~/Dev/
2 Initialize it as a Git repo
3 Create (or connect to) a remote repo on GitHub
4 Add your Jupyter Notebook (for budget plan generation)
5 Commit and push

You can always export the generated CSVs/Excels to Google Sheets for easy phone editing later.

Terminal Commands (Linux/macOS-style)

Below is a copy-pasteable block. Adjust MyBudgetPlanner to whatever name you want: 

# 1 Navigate to your Dev folder
cd ~/Dev/

# 2 Make a new project folder
mkdir MyBudgetPlanner
cd MyBudgetPlanner

# 3 Initialize Git repo
git init

# 4 (Optional) Make a README to describe the project
echo "# My Budget Planner" > README.md
git add README.md
git commit -m "Initial commit with README"

# 5 (Optional) Create a .gitignore for Jupyter notebooks, Python caches, etc.
echo ".ipynb_checkpoints/" > .gitignore
echo "__pycache__/" >> .gitignore
echo "*.pyc" >> .gitignore
git add .gitignore
git commit -m "Add .gitignore"

# 6 Create your first notebook (from Jupyter Lab / Notebook UI)
#    You'd typically launch Jupyter like this:
jupyter lab
# or
jupyter notebook

When Jupyter opens, create your notebook:
BudgetPlan.ipynb

Create the Remote on GitHub

On GitHub.com:
1 Click New repository
2 Name it (e.g. my-budget-planner)
3 Leave it public or private as you prefer
4 Dont initialize with README (you already have one)

Connect and Push

After creating the GitHub repo, youll see GitHub give you this command: 

git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/my-budget-planner.git

Paste that in your terminal.

Then: 

git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

Result

You now have:
Local ~/Dev/MyBudgetPlanner folder with Git
Remote GitHub repo tracking it
Notebook BudgetPlan.ipynb you can edit in JupyterLab

Example File Structure

~/Dev/MyBudgetPlanner/
 .git/
 .gitignore
 README.md
 BudgetPlan.ipynb

Once thats up, you and I can design the notebook contents together:

  • Generate 5-Year Plan CSV

  • Generate Monthly Budget CSV
  • Export to Google Sheets later

2025-07-03T16:25:11.551541Z assistant

Excellent work. Lets clarify what youre seeing:

1 About the Git master warning

You saw:

hint: Using 'master' as the name for the initial branch. ...

Thats just a Git informational message. Its harmless.
It simply says: "Hey, by default your branch is called 'master', but you can rename it to 'main' if you want."

If you want to change it later:

git branch -m main

But you dont have to.

2 About the jupyter command not found

You got:

Command 'jupyter' not found, but can be installed with:
sudo apt install jupyter-core

That only means the jupyter CLI command isnt installed in your PATH.

But you said youre running JupyterLab via the Desktop app.
Thats 100% fine.
No problem at all.

You dont have to install the CLI if you prefer using the Desktop launcher.

3 Next step: Creating the GitHub Repo

Yes! Youre exactly right:

Go to GitHub.com in your browser.
Click New repository.
Recommended settings:

  • Name: OmniversalFinance
  • Description (optional): Personal + Omniversal Media integrated financial planning hub.
  • Private (or Public if you want your choice)
  • Do NOT initialize with:
    • README
    • .gitignore
    • License

Why? You already made the README and .gitignore locally.

Click Create repository.

4 Connect Local to GitHub

Once youve created the repo on GitHub, GitHub will show you these lines:

git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/OmniversalFinance.git
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

If you left your branch as master, use this instead:

git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/OmniversalFinance.git
git push -u origin master

That will connect your local folder to the remote repo and push the initial commit.

YES, those warnings were totally safe to ignore.
YES, use your JupyterLab Desktop appno problem.
YES, you do need to visit GitHub in your browser, create the empty repo, then connect and push.

About JupyterLab CLI

Do you need to install the jupyter CLI right now?

Short Answer:

You dont have to if you're happy using the JupyterLab Desktop app.

The Desktop app opens .ipynb files exactly the same.
The CLI is only needed if you want to launch from terminal.

When You Might Want to Install It

For scripting (e.g. jupyter nbconvert)
For running notebooks headlessly (papermill, etc.)
For developing on remote servers

Recommended Approach

For now, if youre happy with Desktop, skip installing the CLI.

You can always do later: 

sudo apt install jupyter-core

But no rush at all.

TLDR: Your options right now

Option 1: Make your notebook inside Ethan/

Pros:

  • Its cleanly your personal plan.
  • Keeps everything in OmniversalFinance unified.
  • Easy for Git.

Cons:

  • Renees stuff isnt separated unless she uses her folder too.

Option 2: Make it outside (e.g. in ~/Dev first) and copy in

Pros:

  • Lets you draft without cluttering the repo history.
  • Cleaner commits.
  • Lets Renee have a totally fresh notebook template.

Cons:

  • Slightly more manual work to move/copy in.

Option 3 (my favorite): Use Shared_Templates/

Pros:

  • You both share the same master template there.
  • Anyone can clone or copy it into their folder.
  • Clean Git history:
    • Ethan/Ethan_BudgetPlan.ipynb
    • Renee/Renee_BudgetPlan.ipynb
    • Shared_Templates/BudgetTemplate_Generator.ipynb

Cons:

  • Slightly more design upfront (but not bad).

High-level plan for BudgetTemplate_Generator.ipynb

Your notebook will have cells that:

2 Import needed libraries (Python)

4 Define allocation rules (Python)

Ready-to-Paste Cells for JupyterLab

Below Ill write it out as you can literally paste it into your notebook cell by cell:

Cell 1 Title & Intro (Markdown)

#  Omniversal Finance Budget Template Generator

This notebook creates personalized financial planning templates for **Omniversal Media partners**.

 Choose your profile (Ethan, Renee, Omniversal Master)  
 Generate individualized budget templates in correct folders  
 Update the Omniversal *Master Ledger* for allocations  

> *Engineer the bridge today. Fund the runway tomorrow.*

Cell 2 Import Libraries

import pandas as pd
import os
from datetime import datetime

Cell 3 Define User Selector

# Select which budget plan to generate
user_options = ["Ethan", "Renee", "Omniversal"]

print("Available profiles:", user_options)
selected_user = input("Enter profile to generate (Ethan, Renee, Omniversal): ").strip()

if selected_user not in user_options:
    raise ValueError(f"Invalid selection. Choose from {user_options}")

print(f" Generating budget template for: {selected_user}")

Cell 4 Define File Paths

# Define folder paths
base_dir = os.getcwd()
user_folders = {
    "Ethan": os.path.join(base_dir, "Ethan"),
    "Renee": os.path.join(base_dir, "Renee"),
    "Omniversal": os.path.join(base_dir, "Shared_Templates")
}

# Confirm path
target_folder = user_folders[selected_user]
print(f" Target folder: {target_folder}")

Cell 5 Define Common Budget Categories

budget_categories = [
    "Housing", "Utilities", "Food", "Transportation",
    "Phone", "Health", "Debt Payments", "Emergency Fund Savings",
    "Legal Fund Savings", "Retirement Savings", "Omniversal Fund",
    "Personal/Fun", "Other"
]

# Example allocation defaults (can be customized)
default_allocations = [1200, 200, 350, 300, 75, 75, 100, 600, 300, 150, 150, 200, 0]

Cell 6 User-Specific Defaults (Extendable)

# You can customize these for each user in the future
user_income_defaults = {
    "Ethan": 60000,
    "Renee": 45000,    # Placeholder, Renee can edit hers later
    "Omniversal": 0    # For the master ledger it's allocations only
}

annual_income = user_income_defaults.get(selected_user, 0)
monthly_income = annual_income / 12 if annual_income else 0

print(f" Annual income baseline for {selected_user}: ${annual_income}")
print(f" Estimated monthly income: ${monthly_income}")

Cell 7 Build the Budget DataFrame

monthly_budget = pd.DataFrame({
    "Category": budget_categories,
    "Planned $": default_allocations,
    "Actual $": [0]*len(budget_categories),
    "Notes": ["" for _ in budget_categories]
})

monthly_budget

Cell 8 Add Metadata for Saving

today_str = datetime.today().strftime('%Y-%m-%d')
filename = f"{selected_user}_Monthly_Budget_{today_str}.csv"

save_path = os.path.join(target_folder, filename)
print(f" Saving to: {save_path}")

Cell 9 Save Individual Template

# Ensure folder exists
os.makedirs(target_folder, exist_ok=True)

# Save CSV
monthly_budget.to_csv(save_path, index=False)
print(f" Individual budget template saved for {selected_user}.")

Cell Update Omniversal Master Ledger

# Define Omniversal Master Ledger path
master_ledger_path = os.path.join(base_dir, "Shared_Templates", "Omniversal_Master_Ledger.csv")

# Load or initialize
if os.path.exists(master_ledger_path):
    master_ledger = pd.read_csv(master_ledger_path)
else:
    master_ledger = pd.DataFrame(columns=["Date", "User", "Category", "Planned $", "Notes"])

# Append this run
for i, row in monthly_budget.iterrows():
    master_ledger = pd.concat([master_ledger, pd.DataFrame({
        "Date": [today_str],
        "User": [selected_user],
        "Category": [row["Category"]],
        "Planned $": [row["Planned $"]],
        "Notes": [row["Notes"]]
    })], ignore_index=True)

# Save master ledger
master_ledger.to_csv(master_ledger_path, index=False)
print(f" Omniversal Master Ledger updated.")

Cell 11 Completion Message (Markdown)

##  All done!
Your personalized budget template has been generated and saved.

 Individual CSV in your folder  
 Omniversal Master Ledger updated

> *Engineer the bridge today. Fund the runway tomorrow.*

Notes for the Future

You can expand this generator with:

  • Custom income inputs
  • Advanced allocation rules
  • Percentage-based sliders
  • Google Sheets API integration
  • Graph visualizations

#  Omniversal Finance Budget Template Generator

Welcome to the **Omniversal Finance** planning system.

This notebook lets you **generate personal budget templates** for any Omniversal Media partner **AND** maintain a shared **Omniversal Master Ledger** for collective allocations.

 Choose your profile (Ethan, Renee, Omniversal Master, future partners)  
 Generate individualized CSV templates in correct folders  
 Append to the Omniversal Master Ledger for allocation planning

> *Engineer the bridge today. Fund the runway tomorrow.*

Cell 2: Imports

(Code cell)

import pandas as pd
import os
from datetime import datetime

Cell 3: User/Profile Selector

(Code cell)

# Choose which partner to generate a budget plan for
user_options = ["Ethan", "Renee", "Omniversal"]

print("Available profiles:", user_options)
selected_user = input("Enter profile to generate (Ethan, Renee, Omniversal): ").strip()

if selected_user not in user_options:
    raise ValueError(f" Invalid selection. Choose from {user_options}")

print(f" Generating budget template for: {selected_user}")

Cell 4: Define Folder Paths

(Code cell)

# Define where each user's budgets are stored
base_dir = os.getcwd()

user_folders = {
    "Ethan": os.path.join(base_dir, "Ethan"),
    "Renee": os.path.join(base_dir, "Renee"),
    "Omniversal": os.path.join(base_dir, "Shared_Templates")
}

target_folder = user_folders[selected_user]
print(f" Target folder for CSV export: {target_folder}")

Cell 5: Define Budget Categories & Default Allocations

(Code cell)

# Standard budget categories
budget_categories = [
    "Housing", "Utilities", "Food", "Transportation",
    "Phone", "Health", "Debt Payments", "Emergency Fund Savings",
    "Legal Fund Savings", "Retirement Savings", "Omniversal Fund",
    "Personal/Fun", "Other"
]

# Default planned allocation in dollars (editable later)
default_allocations = [1200, 200, 350, 300, 75, 75, 100, 600, 300, 150, 150, 200, 0]

Cell 6: User Income Defaults

(Code cell)

# Define income baselines for each user
user_income_defaults = {
    "Ethan": 60000,
    "Renee": 45000,     # Placeholder, to be personalized by Renee
    "Omniversal": 0     # Master ledger is for aggregate allocations
}

annual_income = user_income_defaults.get(selected_user, 0)
monthly_income = annual_income / 12 if annual_income else 0

print(f" Annual income baseline for {selected_user}: ${annual_income}")
print(f" Estimated monthly income: ${monthly_income}")

Cell 7: Build the Budget DataFrame

(Code cell)

monthly_budget = pd.DataFrame({
    "Category": budget_categories,
    "Planned $": default_allocations,
    "Actual $": [0]*len(budget_categories),
    "Notes": ["" for _ in budget_categories]
})

monthly_budget

Cell 8: Define Save Path

(Code cell)

today_str = datetime.today().strftime('%Y-%m-%d')
filename = f"{selected_user}_Monthly_Budget_{today_str}.csv"

save_path = os.path.join(target_folder, filename)
print(f" Ready to save budget template to: {save_path}")

Cell 9: Save Individual Budget CSV

(Code cell)

# Ensure the folder exists
os.makedirs(target_folder, exist_ok=True)

# Save the CSV
monthly_budget.to_csv(save_path, index=False)
print(f" Individual budget template saved for {selected_user}.")

Cell 10: Update Omniversal Master Ledger

(Code cell)

# Master ledger path
master_ledger_path = os.path.join(base_dir, "Shared_Templates", "Omniversal_Master_Ledger.csv")

# Load existing or create new
if os.path.exists(master_ledger_path):
    master_ledger = pd.read_csv(master_ledger_path)
else:
    master_ledger = pd.DataFrame(columns=["Date", "User", "Category", "Planned $", "Notes"])

# Append this budget run
for i, row in monthly_budget.iterrows():
    master_ledger = pd.concat([master_ledger, pd.DataFrame({
        "Date": [today_str],
        "User": [selected_user],
        "Category": [row["Category"]],
        "Planned $": [row["Planned $"]],
        "Notes": [row["Notes"]]
    })], ignore_index=True)

# Save master ledger
master_ledger.to_csv(master_ledger_path, index=False)
print(f" Omniversal Master Ledger updated.")

Cell 11: Completion Message

(Markdown cell)

##  All done!

Your personalized budget template has been generated and saved.

 Individual CSV saved in the correct user folder  
 Omniversal Master Ledger updated with this run

2 Cell 2 of 9 Import Libraries

# 2 Import Libraries

**What it's for:**  
Load required Python packages.

**What it does:**  
Imports pandas (for dataframes), os (for file paths), and datetime (for timestamping).

**Why it exists:**  
These libraries make it possible to:

 Create budget tables  
 Save CSVs in the right folders  
 Time-stamp each template

3 Cell 3 of 9 User/Profile Selector

# 3 User/Profile Selector

**What it's for:**  
Selects *who* the budget is being generated for.

**What it does:**  
Prompts the user to choose between Ethan, Renee, or Omniversal.

**Why it exists:**  
Ensures the template is created in the correct folder with the right metadata.  
 Lets new users like Renee easily pick their profile.  
 Keeps Omniversal Master Ledger updates organized by user.

4 Cell 4 of 9 Define Folder Paths

# 4 Define Folder Paths

**What it's for:**  
Specifies where to save the generated budget file.

**What it does:**  
Maps each user to their folder:

 Ethan/  
 Renee/  
 Shared_Templates/ (for Omniversal)

**Why it exists:**  
Keeps individual and master budgets separated but consistent.  
 Supports adding future partners with ease.

5 Cell 5 of 9 Budget Categories & Default Allocations

# 5 Budget Categories & Default Allocations

**What it's for:**  
Defines the standard expense categories everyone uses.

**What it does:**  
Creates a list of common budget categories and default dollar allocations.

**Why it exists:**  
 Ensures consistency across everyone's templates.  
 Gives partners an editable starting point.  
 Simplifies comparing and aggregating data in the Omniversal Master Ledger.

6 Cell 6 of 9 User Income Defaults

# 6 User Income Defaults

**What it's for:**  
Sets an initial annual income baseline for each user.

**What it does:**  
Assigns Ethan's and Renee's default incomes (editable later).  
Omniversal's is set to $0 since it's an aggregate ledger.

**Why it exists:**  
 Personalizes budget templates.  
 Gives each partner an automatic monthly income estimate.  
 Supports tailored planning for everyone's unique situation.

7 Cell 7 of 9 Build the Budget DataFrame

# 7 Build the Budget DataFrame

**What it's for:**  
Creates the main budget table.

**What it does:**  
Builds a DataFrame with:

 Category  
 Planned $  
 Actual $ (set to 0)  
 Notes

**Why it exists:**  
 Gives everyone an editable CSV template.  
 Makes it easy to track, update, and visualize personal budgets.

8 Cell 8 of 9 Save Individual Budget CSV

# 8 Save Individual Budget CSV

**What it's for:**  
Writes the personal budget plan to a CSV file.

**What it does:**  
Saves the DataFrame as a CSV in the correct user folder, timestamped with today's date.

**Why it exists:**  
 Lets each partner keep a clean personal record.  
 Ensures organized, dated archives for future comparison and auditing.

9 Cell 9 of 9 Update Omniversal Master Ledger

# 9 Update Omniversal Master Ledger

**What it's for:**  
Maintains the central Omniversal ledger.

**What it does:**  
 Loads existing master ledger or creates new one.  
 Appends this budget's planned allocations, tagged by user and date.  
 Saves the updated master ledger CSV.

**Why it exists:**  
 Enables shared strategic planning.  
 Tracks all partner contributions and allocations over time.  
 Supports collective decision-making while respecting individual sovereignty.

##  Why Omniversal Finance Exists

> *"Your Mother is calling... Can you hear her?"*  Nahko, *Dear Brother*

Omniversal Finance is not just a budgeting spreadsheet or a business planning tool.  

It is a living, breathing commitment to **answer that call**.  

We built this system for those who refuse to be owned. For those who hear the voice of the Earth  and remember we belong to Her. For those who know their time, energy, money, and creativity are **not commodities** but **medicine**.

---

##  Our Mission

 Build personal financial plans that are *actually* personal  
 Respect each individual's sovereignty while enabling shared goals  
 Create a collective **Omniversal Master Ledger** for transparent, equitable funding  
 Support each partner in saving, investing, and building their own dreams  
 Enable collaborative projects without top-down control

---

##  Our Philosophy

We understand that true partnership means **no one is forced to serve someone else's empire**.  

Omniversal Finance is designed so that:

 Ethan can fund his AI-Human Relations pipeline without losing track of daily needs  
 Renee can save for *Rebuilding Roots* and *HotBox* while staying secure  
 Future partners can plug in and *self-manage* without asking permission

It's about building an **Umbrella Corporation** that protects, but does not direct, the movements of those under its canopy.  

So that when our people move, they move **unimpeded**.  
So that we have the legal, financial, and moral infrastructure to say:  

> *No, thank you, Uncle Sam. You don't get to extract from us what isn't yours.*  

---

##  The Medicine of This Work

2025-10-04T12:39:00.187000Z user

got that script?

2025-10-04T12:39:05.772606Z system

2025-10-04T12:39:05.782029Z assistant

Yes I do. Here's a clean, ready-to-run Python script that scaffolds a personal finance folder structure inside your ~/Dev/OmniversalFinance/ directory.

generate_partner_folders.py

#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Omniversal Finance - Partner Folder Scaffolding Script

This script creates a standard folder structure for a specified partner
(e.g., Ethan, Renee, Cody) under ~/Dev/OmniversalFinance/

Run it once per partner to organize:
- Budgets
- Ledger
- Goals
- Notes
- Archive

Written with future collaborators in mind.
"""

import os

# === Configuration ===

# Base directory where the OmniversalFinance repo lives
BASE_DIR = os.path.expanduser("~/Dev/OmniversalFinance")

# Partner name to scaffold (change this as needed)
partner_name = "Ethan"  # e.g., "Renee", "Cody", etc.

# Subfolders to create inside the partner directory
subfolders = [
    "Budgets",
    "Ledger",
    "Goals",
    "Notes",
    "Archive"
]

# === Script Logic ===

def scaffold_partner_folders(base_dir, name, folders):
    partner_path = os.path.join(base_dir, name)
    
    if not os.path.exists(partner_path):
        print(f" Creating main folder: {partner_path}")
        os.makedirs(partner_path)
    else:
        print(f" Partner folder already exists: {partner_path}")

    for folder in folders:
        folder_path = os.path.join(partner_path, folder)
        if not os.path.exists(folder_path):
            os.makedirs(folder_path)
            print(f" Created: {folder_path}")
        else:
            print(f" Already exists: {folder_path}")

    print("\n Folder structure complete.\n")

# === Run ===

if __name__ == "__main__":
    print(f"\n  Scaffolding folders for partner: {partner_name}\n")
    scaffold_partner_folders(BASE_DIR, partner_name, subfolders)

Instructions to Use

  1. Save the script to your repo:
    Example path: 

    ~/Dev/OmniversalFinance/generate_partner_folders.py

  2. Edit the partner_name variable as needed:

    partner_name = "Renee"

  3. Run it from terminal:

    python3 generate_partner_folders.py

  4. It will safely skip folders that already exist.

Example Output

  Scaffolding folders for partner: Ethan

 Partner folder already exists: /home/selene/Dev/OmniversalFinance/Ethan
 Created: /home/selene/Dev/OmniversalFinance/Ethan/Budgets
 Created: /home/selene/Dev/OmniversalFinance/Ethan/Ledger
 Created: /home/selene/Dev/OmniversalFinance/Ethan/Goals
 Created: /home/selene/Dev/OmniversalFinance/Ethan/Notes
 Created: /home/selene/Dev/OmniversalFinance/Ethan/Archive

 Folder structure complete.

Next (when youre ready):

Use the notebook generator to export .csv files into Budgets/ or Ledger/
Use Goals/ for tracking savings targets
Notes/ for reflections, budget logs, etc.
Archive/ for old versions, snapshots

Let me know if you want this to auto-detect or take CLI args (e.g., --partner Renee).
Otherwise ready to push this into the repo now?
